headline: OSB GROUP PLC - Transaction in Own Shares
summary: OSB GROUP PLC ISIN: GB00BLDRH36015 December 2025 LEI number: 213800ZBKL9BHSL2K459 OSB GROUP PLC (the “Company”) Transaction in Own Shares The Company announces that on 12 December 2025 it had purchased a total of 20,000 of its ordinary shares of £0.01 each (the "ordinary shares") on the London Stock Exchange, CBOE BXE and CBOE CXE, through the Company's broker Citigroup Global Markets Limited as detailed below. The repurchased ordinary shares will be cancelled. London Stock ExchangeCBOE BXECBOE

headline: BTQ Technologies Added to Defiance Quantum ETF (QTUM)
summary: BTQ Technologies Corp. ("BTQ" or the "Company") (Nasdaq: BTQ) (CBOE CA: BTQ) (FSE: NG3), a global quantum technology company focused on securing mission-critical networks, is pleased to announce that it has been added to the Defiance Quantum ETF (NASDAQ: QTUM), a thematic exchange traded fund that seeks to track the performance of the BlueStar Machine Learning and Quantum Computing Index ("BQTUM").

headline: Nasdaq seeks to extend trading hours to nearly round-the-clock
summary:
STORY: :: File

The Nasdaq is seeking to roll out near round-the-clock trading of stocks.

The stock exchange is one of the world’s largest and home to tech heavyweights Nvidia, Apple and Amazon.

It plans to file paperwork to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to expand trading hours from 16 hours a day to 23 hours a day, five days a week.

Nasdaq’s plans would see its trading week kick off on Sunday at 9 p.m. Eastern and end Friday at 8 p.m.

:: File

A trading day would be split into two sessions with an hour break at 8 p.m. for maintenance, then start back up at 9 p.m., and would still feature opening and closing bells.

It follows plans announced both by the New York Stock Exchange and Cboe Global Markets for those exchanges to move to nonstop five-day-a-week trading.

Investor demand for nonstop trading of U.S. stocks has surged in recent years.

That’s led regulators to introduce new rules and allow proposals from major exchanges to enable trading beyond traditional market hours.

Today the U.S. stock market represents almost two-thirds of the market value of listed companies around the globe…

…and foreign holdings of U.S. equities hit $17 trillion last year, according to Nasdaq data.

Advocates for moving closer to 24/7 trading argue it will allow investors, especially those outside the U.S., to react more quickly to events that happen outside regular market hours.

Major Wall Street banks are cautious about the push, pointing to anxiety over lower liquidity, more volatility, and uncertainty over returns on investment.
